course_title: Management of Adult Voice and Fluency Disorders

learning_outcomes.description: Describe and explain the theoretical foundationsof normal and disordered voice and fluency in adults.(SPA PS Standards 1.1, 1.2)
Identify and apply assessment tools and proceduresto collect and interpret data relevant to adult voice and fluency disorders.(SPA PS Standards 1.5, 3.1, 3.2)

Apply clinical reasoning skills to the interpretation of assessment data to formulate appropriate short-term treatment goals and intervention plansfor adults with voice and fluency disorders.(SPA PS Standards 1.4, 1.6, 1.7, 3.3, 3.4)
Describe and apply principles of person- and family-centred carein the delivery of voice and fluency management, including the importance of shared decision-making.(SPA PS Standards 1.4, 3.4, 3.5)

Recognise the role of cultural and linguistic diversityin the assessment and management of adult voice and fluency disorders, including the needs of gender-diverse individuals.(SPA PS Standards 1.6, 3.5)
Demonstrate professional conduct and communicationconsistent with the Speech Pathology Australia Professional Standards during simulated or classroom-based activities.(SPA PS Standards 1.3, 4.1)

assessments.task_description:
This in-semester exam will assess knowledge and skills acquired from weekly pre-recorded lectures and tutorials in relation to the assessment, diagnosis, and management of voice and fluency disorders (Weeks 1-5). This assessment will encompass short answer questions including case-based questions relating to assessment interpretation, differential diagnosis and management options for voice and fluency disorders. Students will also be required to perform an online assessment of stuttering behaviours and vocal features from a video recording during this exam.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Reflection task: Voice and fluency disorders management and knowledge transfer
assessments.task_description:
Students will be required to submit a 4-5 minute video reflection demonstrating their ability to transfer knowledge and skills from voice disorder management to fluency disorder management in adults.

In this reflection, students will analyse how the principles and skills used in voice disorders management can be applied to fluency disorders, while acknowledging the unique aspects of each condition. Students should consider the common ground between these areas, including assessment, diagnosis, therapy approaches, and interdisciplinary collaboration, and demonstrate how their knowledge and skills in voice disorders provide a foundation for addressing fluency disorders.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assessment task is to be submitted via the course eLearning Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This end of semester exam will assess knowledge and skills acquired from weekly pre-recorded lectures and tutorials in relation to the assessment, diagnosis, and management of voice and fluency disorders with a focus on Weeks 7-13 . This assessment will encompass short answer questions including case-based questions relating to assessment interpretation, differential diagnosis and management of voice and fluency disorders in adulthood.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The Voice/ Fluency Simulation Clinic is a MUST PASS assessment in SPCH3114. The simulation clinic is made up of two (2) sessions. The first clinic will provide an opportunity to synthesise case information, provide patient education and practise intervention techniques in relation to two (2) cases (i.e, one (1) case with a fluency disorder and one (1) case with voice disorder), via a formative assessment of your skills (i.e., performance feedback is provided but does not contribute to overall grade). The second simulation clinic will provide a summative assessment of your performance in relation to the same tasks from simulation clinic 1 in relation to two (2) new cases.

In preparation for the simulation clinic, a tutorial will be conducted in Week 8. Students will attend the voice and fluency simulation clinic sessions in Week 10 and Week 12.

For each simulation session students will be assessed individually. Tutorials in Week 8 are designed to assist students with preparation and practise opportunities for this clinic.

1. Simulation Clinic 1 – Week 10 (Formative) Students will be assessed individually. Feedback will be provided from Practice Educators and simulated patients following the sessions.

2. Simulation Clinic 2 – Week 12 (Summative) Students will be assessed individually under examination conditions.

In this course the recording of an assessment (oral/practical) performance has been waived, a record of student performance will be taken by other means such as audio recording or detailed written notes that can be referred to if a remark is required at a later date.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
In-person lectures (Weeks 1 and 13)

Two in-person lectures will be delivered in this course. An introduction to the course and related assessment will be provided in Week 1, as well as foundational content in relation to adult voice and fluency disorders. In Week 13, a wrap up lecture will be provided, which will include preparation for the end of semester exam.


Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: In-person lectures (Weeks 1 and 13) Two in-person lectures will be delivered in this course. An introduction to the course and related assessment will be provided in Week 1, as well as foundational content in relation to adult voice and fluency disorders. In Week 13, a wrap up lecture will be provided, which will include preparation for the end of semester exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Online self-directed learning

Pre-recorded lecture content will be available on Blackboard across weeks 2-9. It is expected that students will engage with this content prior to attending the weekly tutorials. Up to four (4) hours of pre-recorded lecture material (voice and fluency content combined) will be provided on the course Blackboard site each week.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Online self-directed learning Pre-recorded lecture content will be available on Blackboard across weeks 2-9. It is expected that students will engage with this content prior to attending the weekly tutorials. Up to four (4) hours of pre-recorded lecture material (voice and fluency content combined) will be provided on the course Blackboard site each week.

learning_activities.topic:
Weekly on-campus tutorials

Weekly tutorials (2 x 2 hour tutorials) will be held in weeks 2-5, 7-9, and 11 of semester. Tutorials will be practically-based and will facilitate student understanding and application of the course content. Week 8 and 11 tutorials will focus on simulation preparation and feedback following the formative sessions.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Weekly on-campus tutorials Weekly tutorials (2 x 2 hour tutorials) will be held in weeks 2-5, 7-9, and 11 of semester. Tutorials will be practically-based and will facilitate student understanding and application of the course content. Week 8 and 11 tutorials will focus on simulation preparation and feedback following the formative sessions.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 10 To Week 12(04 May - 24 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Voice/ fluency simulation clinic

In weeks 10 and 12 of semester, students will engage in a voice/ fluency simulation clinic.

This simulation clinic provides students with scaffolded, experiential learning opportunities to develop and demonstrate clinical reasoning and intervention skills with voice and fluency disorders in adulthood.

Formative Simulation Clinic (Week 10) In this low-stakes learning environment, students will work individually with simulated patients. One (1) case will present with a fluency disorder and one (1) case will present with a voice disorder. This session allows students to:

  • Apply clinical reasoning to synthesise case information
  • Practice patient education and counselling skills
  • Implement evidence-based intervention techniques
  • Receive constructive feedback from Practice Educators and simulated patients to refine your clinical approach


The formative nature means students can take risks, learn from mistakes, and develop their skills without grade consequences.

Summative Simulation Clinic (Week 12) Building on the formative experience and feedback, students will demonstrate mastery of the same clinical tasks with two (2) new cases (one fluency, one voice disorder). This individual pass/fail (MUST PASS) assessment under examination conditions will showcase your ability to independently manage adult cases with voice and fluency disorders.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
